case_name: Kedar Pandey v. Narain Bikram Sah

facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 976 and 977 of 1964 are appeals by certificate against the judgment and decree dated March 26, 1964 of the Patna High Court in Election Appeals Nos. 8 and 10 of 1963.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 976 and 977 of 1964. Appeals from the judgment and decree dated March 26, 1964 of the Patna High Court in Election Appeals Nos. 8 and 10 of 1963.

facts.text: Appellant Kedar Pandey and respondent Narain Bikram Sah (Narain Raja) were contesting candidates in 1962 for election to Bihar Legislative Assembly from Ramnagar Constituency in Champaran district.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant Kedar Pandey and the respondent--Narain Bikram Sah hereinafter called Narain Raja  were the companytesting candidates in the year 1962 on behalf of the Congress and Swatantra Party respectively for the election to Bihar Legislative Assembly from Ramnagar Constituency in the district of Champaran.

facts.text: Nomination papers of appellant, respondent, Parmeshwar Prasad Roy and Suleman Khan were accepted by Returning Officer on January 22, 1962 without objection.

anchor.surface_text: The numberination papers of the appellant and the respondent and two others--Parmeshwar Prasad Roy and Suleman Khan-were accepted by the Returning Officer without any objection on January 22, 1962.

facts.text: Parmeshwar Prasad Roy and Suleman Khan withdrew their candidatures after nomination.

anchor.surface_text: Later on the two candidates--Parmeshwar Prasad Roy and Suleman Khan--withdrew their candidatures.

facts.text: Respondent Narain Raja was declared elected as member of Bihar Legislative Assembly by majority of valid votes after the poll.

anchor.surface_text: After the poll the respondent, Narain Raja was declared elected as member of the Bihar Legislative Assembly by majority of valid votes.

facts.text: Kedar Pandey filed election petition on April 11, 1962 challenging respondent's election.

anchor.surface_text: On April 11, 1962 Kedar Pandey filed an election petition challenging the election of the respondent.

facts.text: Petitioner alleged respondent not duly qualified under Art. 173 as not a citizen of India, born in Nepal along with parents and grandparents.

anchor.surface_text: It was alleged by Kedar Pandey that the respondent was number duly qualified under Art. 173 of the Constitution of India to be a candidate for election as he was number a citizen of India. According to Kedar Pandey the respondent, his parents and grand-parents were all born in Nepal

facts.text: Petitioner alleged respondent related to royal family of Nepal and father Rama Raja owned 43 bighas land and house at Barewa in Nepal in which respondent had share.

anchor.surface_text: According to Kedar Pandey the respondent was related to the royal family of Nepal and the father of the respondent---Rama Raja---owned about 43 bighas of land and a house at Barewa in Nepal in which the respondent had a share along with his three other brothers.

facts.text: Respondent contested petition claiming he was Indian citizen, no disqualification under Art. 173, lived in India since birth, resident of Ramnagar Champaran not Barewa, born in Banaras.

anchor.surface_text: The election petition was companytested by the respondent who said that he was an Indian citizen and there was numberdisqualification incurred under Art. 173 of the Constitution. The further case of the respondent was that he had lived in India since his birth and that he was a resident of Ramnagar in the district of Champaran and number of Barewa in Nepal. The respondent claimed that he was born in Banaras and number at Barewa.

facts.text: Election Tribunal held respondent not citizen of India, not qualified under Art. 173, election void, but refused declaration that Kedar Pandey entitled to be elected.

anchor.surface_text: Upon these rival companytentions it was held by the Tribunal that the respondent Narain Raja--was number a citizen of India and, therefore, was number qualified under Art. 173 of the Constitution for being chosen to fill a seat in the Bihar Legislative Assembly. The Tribunal, therefore, declared that the election of the respondent was void. But the Tribunal refused to make a declaration that Kedar Pandey was entitled to be elected

facts.text: High Court set aside Tribunal judgment, upheld respondent's election.

anchor.surface_text: Both the appellant and the respondent preferred separate appeals against the judgment of the Election Tribunal to the High Court of Judicature at Patna. The High Court in appeal set aside the judgment of the Tribunal and upheld the election of the respondent Narain Raja.

facts.text: High Court found respondent born in Banaras on October 10, 1918, living in India from 1939 to 1949 and thereafter.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court found, on examination of the evidence, that Narain Raja, the respondent before us, was born in Banaras on October 10, 1918 and that the respondent was living in India from 1939 right upto 1949 and even thereafter.

facts.text: High Court found respondent acquired domicile of choice in Indian territory long before 1949 under Art. 5(a) and (c).

anchor.surface_text: The High Court further found that long before the year 1949 Narain Raja had acquired a domicile of choice, in Indian territory and, therefore, acquired the status of a citizen of India both-under Art. 5 a  and  c  of the Constitution.

facts.text: Ramnagar estate originally belonged to Shri Prahlad Sen, then to Mohan Vikram Sah (Mohan Raja) after his death.

anchor.surface_text: The history of the family of Narain Raja is closely companynected with the history of Ramnagar estate. It appears that Ramnagar estate in the district of Champaran in Bihar originally belonged to. Shri Prahlad Sen after whose death the estate came into the possession of Shri Mohan Vikram Sah, popularly known as Mohan Raja.

facts.text: Mohan Raja died without male issue but adopted Rama Raja (father of respondent) during lifetime; will in 1904 to wife Rani Chhatra Kumari Devi; Mohan Raja died 1912.

anchor.surface_text: Mohan Raja died without any male issue but during his lifetime he had adopted Rama Raja, the father of the respondent and by virtue of a will executed by Mohan Raja in the year 1904 in favour of his wife Rani Chhatra Kumari Devi the Rani became entitled to the Ramnagar estate on the death of Mohan Raja  which took place in 1912

facts.text: Rani Chhatra Kumari Devi died in 1937; Rama Raja came into possession of Ramnagar estate thereafter.

anchor.surface_text: After the death of Rani L P D 5SCI--12 Chhatra Kumari Devi in 1937 Rama Raja came into the possession of the Ramnagar estate.

facts.text: Partition suit No. 40 of 1942 filed September 29, 1942 by Rama Raja and sons including respondent; preliminary decree April 16, 1943; final decree May 22, 1944.

anchor.surface_text: There is evidence that Rama Raja died in Bombay and his dead-body was cremated in Banaras. It is also in evidence that during the lifetime of Rama Raja there was a partition suit in the year 1942--No. 40 of 1942--for the partition of the properties of the Ramnagar estate among Rama Raja and his sons including the respondent. This suit was filed on September 29, 1942 in the Court of the Subordinate Judge at Motihari. A preliminary decree--Ex. 1 2 --was passed on April 16, 1943

facts.text: Supreme Court notes both courts found respondent ordinarily resident in India for 5 years preceding commencement of Constitution (Art. 5(c)); unchallenged by appellant.

anchor.surface_text: the concurrent findings of both the High Court and the Tribunal that for a period of 5 years preceding the companymencement of the Constitution Narain Raja was ordinarily resident in the territory of India. Therefore the requirement of Art. 5 c  of the Constitution is fulfilled. Mr. Aggarwala on behalf of the appellant did number challenge this finding of the High Court.

facts.text: Narain Raja educated in Calcutta from 1934 to 1938; lived in Ramnagar from 1938 onwards.

anchor.surface_text: The following facts have been either admitted by the parties found to be established in this case. Narain Raja was educated in Calcutta from 1934 to 1938. From the year 1938 onwards Narain Raja lived in Ramnagar.

facts.text: After father's death in 1947, Narain Raja continued to live in Ramnagar, in possession of properties from 1944 partition.

anchor.surface_text: After Rama Rajas death in 1947 Narain Raja companytinued to live in Ramnagar, being in possession of properties obtained by him under companypromise in 1944.

facts.text: Narain Raja obtained Indian Passport dated March 23, 1949 from Lucknow, described as Indian by birth and nationality, address Ramnagar Champaran.

anchor.surface_text: It is also important to numberice that Narain Raja had obtained Indian Passport dated March 23, 1949 from Lucknow issued by the Governor-General of India and he is described in that Passport as Indian by birth and nationality and his address is given as Ramnagar of Champaran district.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds Narain Raja acquired domicile of choice in India long before end of 1949, satisfying Art. 5.

anchor.surface_text: Taking all the events and circumstances of Narain Rajas life into account we are satisfied that long before the end of 1949 which is the material time under Art. 5 of the Constitution, Narain Raja had acquired a domicil of choice in India.

facts.text: Supreme Court finds requirements of Art. 5(c) satisfied as ordinarily resident 5 years preceding Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: We have already referred to the finding of the High Court that Narain Raja was ordinarily resident in India for 5 years immediately preceding the time when Art. 5 of the Constitution came into force.

facts.text: Supreme Court concludes Narain Raja was citizen of India at relevant time under Art. 5.

anchor.surface_text: It is manifest that the requirements of Art. 5 c  of the Constitution are satisfied in this case and the High Court rightly reached the companyclusion that Narain Raja was a citizen of India at the relevant time.

issues.text: whether the respondent was duly qualified under Art. 173 of the Constitution of India to be a candidate for election as he was not a citizen of India

anchor.surface_text: It was alleged by Kedar Pandey that the respondent was not duly qualified under Art. 173 of the Constitution of India to be a candidate for election as he was not a citizen of India. According to Kedar Pandey the respondent, his parents and grand-parents were all born in Nepal and,

issues.text: whether the High Court was right in its conclusion that the respondent-Narain Raja--was a citizen of India under Art. 5 of the Constitution of India on the material date

anchor.surface_text: The main question arising for decision in this case is whether the High Court was right in its conclusion that the respondent-Narain Raja--was a citizen of India under Art. 5 of the Constitution of India on the material date. The history of the family of Narain Raja is closely connected with the history of Ramnagar estate.

issues.text: whether Narain Raja had his domicil in the territory of India at the material time

anchor.surface_text: established and the only question remaining for consideration is the question whether Narain Raja had his domicil in the territory of India at the material time. Upon this question it was argued before the High Court on behalf of the respondent that the domicil of origin of Mohan Raja may have been in Nepal but he had acquired a domicile of choice in India after inheriting Ramnagar Raj from his maternal grandfather Prahlad Sen.

issues.text: whether Narain Raja had acquired the domicil of choice in India

anchor.surface_text: the domicil of origin. The crucial question for determination in this case, therefore. is whether Narain Raja had acquired the domicil of choice in India. The law on the topic is well-established but the difficulty is found in its application to varying combination of circumstances in each case.

issues.text: whether Narain Raja was born in Banaras or at Barewa

anchor.surface_text: We do not, however, think it necessary to express any concluded opinion on this question of fact but proceed to decide the case the assumption that Narain Raja was not born in the territory of India, in the year 1918. The reason is that the place of birth of Narain Raja has lost its importance in this case in view of the concurrent findings of both the High Court and the Tribunal that for a period of 5 years preceding the commencement of the Constitution Narain Raja was ordinarily resident in the territory of India.

arguments.claim: Respondent born in Banaras on October 10, 1918, living in India from 1939 to 1949 and thereafter, acquired domicile of choice before 1949 under Art. 5(a) and (c), duly qualified

anchor.surface_text: The High Court in appeal set aside the judgment of the Tribunal and upheld the election of the respondent Narain Raja. The High Court found, on examination of the evidence, that Narain Raja, the respondent before us, was born in Banaras on October 10, 1918 and that the respondent was living in India from 1939 right upto 1949 and even thereafter.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ndia. In our opinion, the requisite animus manendi has been proved and the finding of the High Court is companyrect. On behalf of the appellant Mr. Ag

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the appellant Mr. Aggarwala put forward the argument that the High Court was not justified in holding that Narain Raja was born in Banaras in the year 1918. According the case of the appellant Narain Raja was born at a place called Barewa in Nepal. In order to prove his case the appellant examined two witnesses---Sheonath Tewari W. 18  and N.D. Pathak  P.W. 15 .

arguments.court_reasoning: Assumed not born in India as irrelevant due to Art. 5(c)

arguments.claim: Mohan Raja acquired domicile of choice in India; by adoption in 1903 Rama Raja acquired Indian domicile; alternatively Rama Raja acquired domicile after 1937 upon possession

anchor.surface_text: Upon this question it was argued before the High Court on behalf of the respondent that the domicil of origin of Mohan Raja may have been in Nepal but he had acquired a domicile of choice in India after inheriting Ramnagar Raj from his maternal grandfather Prahlad Sen. It was said that Mohan Raja had settled down in India and had married all his 4 Ranis in Ramnagar.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ed intention of abandoning the first domicil and aquiring another as the sole domicil is clearly shown  see Winarts v. Attorney-General.  1  In Munro

arguments.court_reasoning: No material on Mohan Raja's domicile; unclear intention for Rama Raja

arguments.claim: No material to decide Mohan Raja's domicile; impossible to ascertain Rama Raja's intention to settle; assume Narain Raja's domicile of origin in Nepal but acquired choice in India

anchor.surface_text: The High Court, however. held, upon examination of the evidence, that there was no material on the record to decide the question of Mohan Rajas domicil. It was also held by the High Court that it was not possible to ascertain from the evidence whether there was any intention of Rama Raja to settle down in India and make it his permanent home.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ndia. In our opinion, the requisite animus manendi has been proved and the finding of the High Court is companyrect. On behalf of the appellant Mr. Ag

arguments.court_reasoning: SC proceeds on assumption of origin Nepal but finds choice acquired

arguments.claim: Domicile of choice requires residence with animus manendi; onus on those asserting change from origin; origin continues unless clear abandonment

anchor.surface_text: The law attributes to every person at birth a domicil which is called a domicil of origin. This domicil may be changed and a new domicil, which is called a domicil of choice, acquired but the two kinds of domicil differ in one respect. The domicil of origin is received by operation of law at birth the domicile of choice is acquired later by the actual removal of an individual to another country accompanied by his animus manendi.

arguments.claim: Only intention for change of domicile is permanent residence, voluntary fixation of home not temporary

anchor.surface_text: We are of the view that the, only intention required for a proof of a change of domicil is an intention of permanent residence. In other words, what is required to be established is that the person who is alleged to have changed his domicil of origin has voluntarily fixed the habitation of himself and his family in the new country, not for a mere special of temporary purpose, but with a present intention of making it his permanent home.

arguments.claim: Narain Raja acquired domicile of choice in India evidenced by education in Calcutta 1934-38, living in Ramnagar from 1938, partition 1944, properties, passport 1949 describing as Indian by birth

anchor.surface_text: The following facts have been either admitted by the parties found to be established in this case. Narain Raja was educated in Calcutta from 1934 to 1938. From the year 1938 onwards Narain Raja lived in Ramnagar. After Rama Rajas death in 1947 Narain Raja continued to live in Ramnagar, being in possession of properties obtained by him under compromise in 1944.

arguments.claim: Conduct before and after relevant date relevant for domicile at material time

anchor.surface_text: The High Court considered that for the determination of the question of domicil of a person at a particular time, the course of his conduct and the facts and circumstances before and after that time are relevant. We consider that the view taken by the High Court on this point is correct

arguments.claim: Narain Raja acquired domicile of choice long before end of 1949, animus manendi proved

anchor.surface_text: Taking all the events and circumstances of Narain Rajas life into account we are satisfied that long before the end of 1949 which is the material time under Art. 5 of the Constitution, Narain Raja had acquired a domicil of choice in India.

arguments.claim: Ordinarily resident in India for 5 years preceding Constitution under Art. 5(c), unchallenged

anchor.surface_text: the concurrent findings of both the High Court and the Tribunal that for a period of 5 years preceding the commencement of the Constitution Narain Raja was ordinarily resident in the territory of India. Therefore the requirement of Art. 5 c  of the Constitution is fulfilled. Mr. Aggarwala on behalf of the appellant did not challenge this finding of the High Court.

arguments.claim: Property in Nepal (Ex. 10c) shows no intention of permanent domicile in India

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the appellant Mr. Aggarwala suggested that there were two reasons to show that Narain Raja had no intention of making his domicil of choice in India. Reference was made, in this context, to Ex. 10 c  which is a khatian prepared in 1960. showing certain properties standing in the name of Narain Raja and his brothers in Nepal.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: a Sanad  Ex. AA . In any event, we are number satisfied that the circumstance of Narain Raja owning the property companyered by Ex. 10 c  can outweigh

arguments.court_reasoning: Does not outweigh extensive properties in India; inherited from grandmother

arguments.claim: Use of title 'Sri 5' indicates intention to retain ties to Nepal royal family

anchor.surface_text: It was also pointed out on behalf of the appellant that Narain Raja, and before him Rama Raja, had insisted upon designating themselves Sri 5, indicating that they belonged to the royal family of Nepal It was argued on behalf of the appellant that Narain Raja had clung tenaciously to the title of Sri 5,

court_response_anchor.surface_text: aditional title and this circumstance has numberbearing on the question of domicil. Succession to throne of Nepal is governed by the rule of primogeni

arguments.court_reasoning: Pride of ancestry and sentiment; no bearing on domicile; unlikely to ascend throne

arguments.claim: Requirements of Art. 5(c) satisfied; citizen at relevant time under Art. 5

anchor.surface_text: It is manifest that the requirements of Art. 5 c  of the Constitution are satisfied in this case and the High Court rightly reached the conclusion that Narain Raja was a citizen of India at the relevant time.

holdings.text: It is not necessary to express any concluded opinion on the question of whether Narain Raja was born in Banaras or Barewa, proceeding on the assumption that he was not born in the territory of India in 1918.

anchor.surface_text: We do not, however, think it necessary to express any concluded opinion on this question of fact but proceed to decide the case the assumption that Narain Raja was not born in the territory ,of India, in the year 1918. The reason is that the place of birth of

holdings.reasoning_summary: Place of birth loses importance due to fulfillment of Art. 5(c) residence requirement via concurrent unchallenged findings.

holdings.text: Narain Raja was ordinarily resident in the territory of India for 5 years preceding the commencement of the Constitution; therefore the requirement of Art. 5(c) is fulfilled.

anchor.surface_text: the concurrent findings of both the High Court and the Tribunal that for a period of 5 years preceding the commencement of the Constitution Narain Raja was ordinarily resident in the territory of India. Therefore the requirement of Art. 5 c  of the Constitution

holdings.reasoning_summary: Concurrent findings of High Court and Tribunal accepted as unchallenged by appellant.

holdings.text: The course of conduct and facts and circumstances before and after the relevant time are relevant for determining domicile at the material time.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court considered that for the determination of the question of domicil of a person at a particular time, the course of his conduct and the facts and circumstances before and after that time are relevant. We consider that the view

holdings.reasoning_summary: Approves High Court's view supported by precedent (In re Grove).

holdings.text: The only intention required to prove a change of domicile of origin is an intention of permanent residence by voluntarily fixing habitation in the new country not for temporary purpose but with present intention of making it permanent home.

anchor.surface_text: We are of the view that the, only intention required for a proof of a change of domicil is an intention of permanent residence. In other words, what is required to be established is that the person who is alleged to have changed his domicil

holdings.reasoning_summary: Derives from precedents Udny v. Udny and Doucet v. Geoghegan rejecting stricter intent requirements.

holdings.text: Narain Raja had acquired a domicile of choice in India long before the end of 1949, the material time under Art. 5 of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: Taking all the events and circumstances of Narain Rajas life into account we are satisfied that long before the end of 1949 which is the material time under Art. 5 of the Constitution, Narain Raja had acquired a domicil of choice in India.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Facts of residence from 1938, education, partition suit, properties acquired, management, passport establish residence and animus manendi; conduct pre-1949 decisive.

holdings.text: The requisite animus manendi has been proved and the finding of the High Court is correct.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the requisite animus manendi has been proved and the finding of the High Court is correct.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Life events demonstrate fixed intention to settle permanently in India.

holdings.text: Narain Raja had acquired domicile of choice in India when Art. 5 of the Constitution came into force.

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons expressed, we hold that Narain Raja had acquired domicil of choice in India when Art. 5 of the Constitution came into force.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative facts and circumstances prove change from domicile of origin.

holdings.text: The requirements of Art. 5(c) of the Constitution are satisfied.

anchor.surface_text: We have already referred to the finding of the High Court that Narain Raja was ordinarily resident in India for 5 years immediately preceding the time when Art. 5 of the Constitution came into force.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court finding on ordinary residence confirmed.

holdings.text: Narain Raja was a citizen of India at the relevant time; High Court rightly reached this conclusion.

anchor.surface_text: It is manifest that the requirements of Art. 5 c of the Constitution are satisfied in this case and the High Court rightly reached the conclusion that Narain Raja was a citizen of India at the relevant time.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Domicile plus Art. 5(c) residence requirements fulfilled.

holdings.text: Respondent Narain Raja was duly qualified under Art. 173 as a citizen of India.

anchor.surface_text: It was alleged by Kedar Pandey that the respondent was not duly qualified under Art. 173 of the Constitution of India to be a candidate for election as he was not a citizen of India.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Citizenship under Art. 5 established, satisfying qualification under Art. 173.

holdings.text: Ownership of minor property in Nepal does not outweigh evidence of extensive properties and settlement in India so as to negate domicile of choice.

anchor.surface_text: In any event, we are not satisfied that the circumstance of Narain Raja owning the property covered by Ex. 10 c can outweigh the fact that Narain Raja alone had extensive properties in India after the partition decree of the year 1944.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Inherited minor share insignificant compared to Indian estate possession and activities.

holdings.text: Prefixing title 'Sri 5' due to pride of ancestry has no bearing on domicile; no substance in argument it indicates retention of Nepal ties.

anchor.surface_text: We do not think there is any substance in this argument. It is likely that Narain Raja and his father Rama Raja had prefixed the title of Sri 5 to their names owing to the pride of their ancestry and sentimental attachment to the traditional

holdings.reasoning_summary: Sentimental title use does not evidence intent to retain Nepal domicile; primogeniture rules make throne claim implausible.

anchor.surface_text: see Winarts v. Attorney-General.  1  In Munro v. Munro 2  Lord Cottonham states the rule as follows The domicil of origin must prevail until the party has n

precedents.cited_proposition: The domicil of origin continues unless a fixed and settled intention of abandoning the first domicil and acquiring another as the sole domicil is clearly shown

anchor.surface_text: In Munro v. Munro 2  Lord Cottonham states the rule as follows The domicil of origin must prevail until the party has number only acquired another, but has manifested and carried into execution an intention of abandoning his former domicil

precedents.cited_proposition: Domicil of origin must prevail until the party has not only acquired another, but has manifested and carried into execution an intention of abandoning his former domicil, and acquiring another as his sole domicil
precedents.cited_holding: To effect this abandonment of the domicil of origin... there must be both residence and intention. Residence alone has no effect, per se, though it may be most important as a ground from which to infer intention.

precedents.citation: Aikman v. Aikman 1 3 Mac Q., H.L.C. 854

anchor.surface_text: In Aikman v. Aikman 1 , Lord Campbell has discussed the question of the effect on domicil of an intention to return to the native country, where such intention is attributable to an undefined and remote contingency.

precedents.cited_proposition: Effect on domicile of an intention to return to the native country on a doubtful contingency
precedents.cited_holding: If a man is settled in a foreign country... a mere intention to return... will not prevent... domicil of origin. But a residence... accompanied by an intention of going back... cannot be considered as indicating the purpose to live and die abroad.

precedents.citation: Moorhouse v. Lord 2 10 H.L. Cas. 272. L.R. 1 H.L. Sc. 441

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the appellant Mr. Aggarwala relied on the decision of the House of Lords in Moorhouse v. Lord 2  in which it was held that in order to lose a domicil of origin, and to acquire a new domicil, a man must intend quatenus in illo exuere patriam

precedents.cited_proposition: To lose a domicil of origin and acquire a new one, must intend to exuere patriam (cast off native allegiance) and there must be change of nationality

precedents.citation: Udny v. Udny 3 L.R. 1 H.L. Sc. 441

anchor.surface_text: But the principle laid down in this case was discussed in Udny v. Udny 3  which decision is the leading authority on what constitute a domicil of choice taking the place of a domicil of origin.

precedents.cited_proposition: Leading authority on what constitutes a domicil of choice; expressions in Moorhouse as to intent exuere patriam are misleading
precedents.cited_holding: Domicil of choice is a conclusion... from the fact of a man fixing voluntarily his sole or chief residence in a particular place, with the intention of continuing to reside there for an unlimited time... residence freely chosen... fixed, not for a limited period...

anchor.surface_text: In the next case--Doucet v. Geoghegan 1  the Court of Appeal decided that the testator had acquired an English domicil and one of the main facts relied on was that he had twice married in England

precedents.cited_proposition: Acquisition of domicile based on acts like marriage, bringing up children, making will in the country; vague declarations to return do not outweigh facts

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the decisions of the English Courts in Udny Undy 3  and Doucet v. Geoghegan 1  represent the correct law with regard to change of domicil of origin.

precedents.cited_proposition: Correct law on change of domicil of origin (along with Doucet)

precedents.citation: In re Grove Vaucher v. The Solicitor to the Treasury 1 1889 40 Oh. D. 216

anchor.surface_text: This view is borne out by the decision of the Chancery Court in In re Grove Vaucher v. The Solicitor to the Treasury 1  in which the domicil of one Marc Thomegay in 1744 was at issue and various facts

precedents.case_name: In re Grove; Vaucher v Solicitor to the Treasury
precedents.cited_proposition: For determination of domicile at a particular time, conduct and acts before, at, and after that time are relevant evidence of intention
precedents.cited_holding: To determine a person's intention at a given time, you may regard not only conduct... before and at the time, but also conduct... after the time, assigning... proper weight of cogency.

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons expressed, we hold that Narain Raja had acquired domicil of choice in India when Art. 5 of the Constitution came into force. We have already referred to the finding of the High Court that Narain Raja was ordinarily resident in India for 5 years immediately preceding the time when Art. 5 of the Constitution came into force. It is manifest that the requirements of Art. 5 c of the Constitution are satisfied in this case and the High Court rightly reached the conclusion that Narain Raja was a citizen of India at the relevant time.

outcome.relief_summary: Respondent Narain Raja held to be citizen of India under Art. 5; qualified to contest election; High Court judgment upheld; election petition dismissed

edges.explanation: Issue of domicile in India territory addresses domicile of choice concept
The issue concerning acquisition of domicile of choice in India addresses the concept of domicile of origin, as acquiring a domicile of choice involves abandoning the domicile of origin.

The issue of whether Narain Raja acquired domicile of choice in India requires animus manendi, defined as the fixed and settled purpose of making a permanent home with deliberate intention to settle indefinitely.
Issue of domicile acquisition requires onus concept for change of domicile.
Issue of whether acquired domicile of choice requires the concept of domicile of choice
Issue requires holding on proof of animus manendi.
Winarts v Attorney-General states domicile of origin continues unless fixed and settled intention to abandon and acquire new, supporting the onus on party asserting change.
Precedent on intention requirement supports holding that animus manendi proved.
Precedent on fixed intention for domicile change supports determining if Narain Raja acquired Indian domicile.
Munro v Munro states domicile of origin prevails until party manifests intention to abandon and acquire new, supporting the onus concept.
Precedent on manifested intention supports holding on proof of animus.
Precedent on manifesting intention for domicile change supports issue of acquisition of domicile of choice.
